comments:
Rhetoric and the Community is a class designed to improve the quality of students’ speaking abilities. Through debates, impromptu speeches and various other types of oral reports, students develop their skills as speakers. The emphasis here is on practical advice, constant positive criticism and an active exploration of the art of oratory.   The role of effective oral communication in contributing to a higher level of engagement and discourse in the community is emphasized. This class will particularly help those planning careers in advocacy, public service, teaching and other areas where confident, thoughtful, and articulate communication are important.

	Students unanimously loved this course, described as “one of the best classes I’ve ever taken,” “the best class ever” and “the most useful class I’ve taken in college.” The course was “highly rewarding” in promoting a “practical application of ancient concepts”, and students loved how it was “feedback oriented, equally from classmates and the professor.” Though it pushed students to “learn so much,” it was also described as “a lot of fun,” and students all felt they had progressed in their abilities by the end of the semester.

	Professor McInerney was beloved by his students. He was called “a wizard at public speaking” and an “outstanding teacher.” Multiple students commented on his willingness to work one-on-one with students, and loved how he took “a legitimate interest in the development and personal well-being of his students.” There was not a single criticism given for Professor McInerney, and many students said “everyone should take at least one class with him.”

	Students felt the work in this course was incredibly rewarding, appreciating the “collaborative effort for everyone in the class to improve.” While one student noted there was “more work than expected in terms of writing and revising speeches,” they added, “it was all worth it.” This course was recommended to anyone looking to work on public speaking skills, with one student saying “freshmen should be required to take a class like this, and Jeremy McInerney should be cloned in order to teach all of them.”
